description: Here, the reinforcement learning specific data of assume will be plotted. Especially the process during the learning

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datetime AS "time",
  power
FROM market_dispatch
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
ORDER BY 1

options.content:
#### Introduction

Here we visualize the results of the reinforcment learning process for the specified units that us a learning strategy. Reinforcement Learning is a machine learning paradigm where an agent learns to make a sequence of decisions in an environment to maximize a reward signal. The agent explores the environment, takes actions, and receives feedback in the form of rewards. The goal is to learn a strategy (policy) that guides the agent to make actions that lead to the highest cumulative reward over time. To better understand the agent's learning process, we use visualizations that illustrate key aspects of its journey.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datetime AS "time",
  power
FROM market_dispatch
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
ORDER BY 1

options.content:
#### How to use the dashboard

This interactive tool is designed to help you gain insights into the learning journey of our reinforcement learning (RL) agent. 
To understand the dashboard take note of the following three points:

##### 1. Division of the Dashboard:
The dashboard is divided into two parts. The upper part summarizes the results for all learning units over all simulated episodes. The lower part focuses the results on speicifc units and episodes, which you can select according to the second point.


##### 2. Selection of Metrics and Simulation Subsets:
The dashboard is devided in system wide plots and plots spefically for certain episodes, timeframes and learning units.
On the top of the dashboard, you'll find a list of available choices for the episode of the simualtiona and a list of RL units. 
Choose the ones you're interested in by selecting on their names in the list. The selected metrics will be displayed on the Choice specific visualization area.


##### 3. Interaction with Plots:
The plots are interactive. You can zoom in and out, click on data points to view specific details etc.


If you need some guidance for interpreting the results, you can orient yourself on the follwing steps:

1. Understand Learning Trends: Observe how reward, exploration, and other metrics change over time. Look for trends such as increasing rewards, decreasing episode length, and changes in exploration patterns.
2. Examine Policy and Action Patterns: Visualize the agent's learned policy and action distribution. Darker shades indicate preferred actions, while lighter shades show less preferred ones.
3. Monitor Learning Curve and Loss: Keep an eye on the learning curve to see how the agent's performance evolves. If applicable, check the loss curve to understand the convergence of the learning algorithm.
4. Track Success Rate: If success/failure in an auction is relevant, track the success rate plot to gauge the agent's success in completing a trade. Note that sometimes the circumstances might not allow a successfull trade.
5. Compare Different Strategies: If multiple algorithms or learning parameter sets are available, use the comparison plot to assess their performance. Select the ones you want to compare, and observe how their learning trajectories differ.
6. Experiment and Learn: Use this tool to experiment with different settings and learn about RL agent behavior. It's a great way to develop a deeper understanding of reinforcement learning concepts.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datetime AS "time",
  power
FROM market_dispatch
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'
and learning_mode is true

panels.title: Average reward of all learning units

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'
and evaluation_mode is true

panels.title: Average evaluation reward of all learning units

targets.rawSql:
-- this query creates a cumulative sum of the reward until now
SELECT 
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  'episode ' || episode AS "episode",
  sum(sum(reward)) OVER (PARTITION BY episode ORDER BY datetime) AS "reward"
FROM
  rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime) 
  and simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'
GROUP BY 1, datetime, episode
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: Cumulative avergage REWARD over all Units per episode

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  'episode ' || episode AS "episode",
  sum(sum(profit)) OVER (PARTITION BY episode ORDER BY datetime) AS "profit"
FROM
  rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
  and simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'
GROUP BY 1, datetime, episode
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: Cumulative avergage PROFIT over all Units per episode

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  avg(accepted_volume/volume) AS "accepted_volume"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time)
  and simulation = '$simulation'
GROUP BY 1, start_time
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: Average Accepted Volume Ratio for all Units

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit'

SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  profit
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit'

SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  regret
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit'

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  price AS "Bid price:",
  bid_id as "bid_id"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time) AND
  simulation = '$simulation'
  AND unit_id = '$rl_unit'
GROUP BY 1, unit_id, price, bid_id
ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  volume AS "Bid volume:",
  bid_id as "bid_id"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time) AND
  simulation = '$simulation'
  AND unit_id = '$rl_unit'
GROUP BY 1, unit_id, volume, bid_id
ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  actions_0 AS "action_Pinflex",
  actions_0+exploration_noise_0 AS "noisy_action_Pinflex",
  simulation AS "simulation"
FROM rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime) AND
  simulation = '$simulation' AND
  unit = '$rl_unit'

ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  actions_1 AS "action_Pflex",
  actions_1+exploration_noise_1 AS "noisy_action_Pflex",
  simulation AS "simulation"
FROM rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime) AND
  simulation = '$simulation' AND
  unit = '$rl_unit'

ORDER BY 1

list.definition:
SELECT DISTINCT
SUBSTRING(m.simulation, 0, LENGTH(m.simulation) +1  - strpos(REVERSE(m.simulation),'_')) AS market_simulation
FROM rl_params m
where learning_mode = True
list.description: Can choose which simulation we want to show
list.name: simulation
list.query:
SELECT DISTINCT
SUBSTRING(m.simulation, 0, LENGTH(m.simulation) +1  - strpos(REVERSE(m.simulation),'_')) AS market_simulation
FROM rl_params m
where learning_mode = True

list.definition:
SELECT DISTINCT unit
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'
list.description: All units that have an reinforcment learning strategy and hence have the Rl specific parameteres logged
list.label: rl_unit
list.name: rl_unit
list.query:
SELECT DISTINCT unit
FROM rl_params
where simulation like '${simulation}' || '_%'

title: Assume: Training progress
